awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Engineering Biomaterials that Leverage Size-Dependent Biological Effects of Hyaluronic Acid to Promote Spinal Cord Regeneration
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Seidlits, Stephanie
Proposal #:  1653730

Over 1 million people in the USA live with spinal cord injury (SCI) for which no current clinical treatment can restore function.  Barriers to spinal cord regeneration include loss of functional neural circuits, extensive cell death, astrocyte induced scar formation, and chronic inflammation.  Hyaluronic acid (HA)---a viscous fluid carbohydrate that is the main structural component of the extracellular matrix (ECM)--is an important mediator in each of these events.  In healthy spinal cord, HA remains in its native, high molecular weight form (nHA, molecular weight > 300 kDA) and acts to maintain tissue structure, protect against oxidative stress, and promote quiescence of astrocytes and neural stem cells (NSCs). Immediately after injury, nHA is degraded into a range of smaller fragments (fHA, molecular weight = 1-100 kDa), which are thought to have size-dependent actions on wound-healing processes including direct effects on astrocyte proliferation, angiogenesis and NSC recruitment.  Studies examining the effects of HA biomaterials relative to reducing scarring and promoting NSC differentiation have produced conflicting results. The PI posits that these discrepancies arise from failure to experimentally control for differences in HA molecular weight. Thus, the goal of this project is to provide a fundamental understanding of how the diverse biological effects of HA can be leveraged to engineer biomaterials that effectively direct tissue repair after SCI by investigating: 1) how the molecular weight of HA incorporated into crosslinked hydrogels affects cell-biomaterial interactions and 2) how these molecular weight-dependent effects can be used to design HA biomaterials with improved therapeutic benefits. The integrated research and education plan includes mentored laboratory experiences for high school, undergraduate and graduate students that are designed to generate enthusiasm for science and engineering in medicine that will motivate future career goals, e.g.: 1) fluorescent reporters that enable students to visualize subcellular processes in real-time and 2) the promise of new clinical treatments for spinal cord repair.  Research results will be integrated into two UCLA undergraduate bioengineering courses with unique hands-on, laboratory components, including the CAPSTONE design course where groups of seniors work closely with an interdisciplinary team of academic and industry mentors to design and construct new solutions to important biomedical problems.

As part of the long-term goal to engineer improved therapies to promote nerve regeneration, the focus of this project is to improve understanding of how the molecular weight-dependent bioactivities of HA affect spinal cord repair. Specifically, the PI aims to identify the molecular weight-dependent effects of HA on human cells relevant to SCI (NSCs and astrocytes) and apply this information to design HA-releasing biomaterials to guide spinal cord regeneration. Multiple studies have demonstrated that nHA--which degrades to fHA after SCI-- inhibits astrocyte proliferation and reactivity. In opposition, disruption of the nHA matrix promotes astrocyte proliferation and activation and, as a result, increased glial scarring. A few studies have reported similar effects on NSCs. Despite the known dependence of HA bioactivity on molecular weight, HA chain size has not been a significant consideration in the development of regenerative biomaterials.   Aim 1 will investigate how the molecular weight of HA crosslinked into hydrogel biomaterials affects CD44 (a receptor for HA)-mediated bioactivity of cells integral to spinal cord repair (NSCs and astrocytes). Aim 2 will characterize the molecular weight profile of HA fragments released from biomaterials during biodegradation and assess the effects of its products on chemotaxis and proliferation of NSCs and astrocytes. Aim 3 will work towards clinical translation by developing HA-based hydrogels that are injectable, support robust cell infiltration and enable temporal control over HA molecular weight. This aim includes the novel fabrication of injectable, macroporous scaffolds with defined HA molecular weights, including nHA, which has not previously been accomplished due to the high viscosity of nHA. Effects of the hydrogels on NSCs and inflammation will be evaluated in a mouse model of acute SCI, whose outcome will be followed 4 weeks post injury.  Thus, the project will provide a fundamental understanding of the molecular weight-dependent bioactivities of HA and guide the design of advanced HA-based therapeutics, in particular for spinal cord regeneration but with implications for a broad range of medical applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop hyaluronic acid (HA)-based biomaterial strategies for spinal cord repair. There are currently no clinical treatments available for patients living with spinal cord injury (SCI). HA-based biomaterials have been shown to be a promising strategy for SCI treatment due to their compatibility with the body, easy fabrication, and capability to be delivered in a minimally invasive injection. However, HA has also been shown to be exhibit a size-dependent bioactivity where small HA fragments induce inflammatory responses and native, large HA chains induce anti-inflammatory responses. At the time of this proposal, the mechanism behind and the influence of crosslinking HA into biomaterials on this bioactivity remained unexplored. This project set out to achieve three main goals: 1) characterize how the common practice of crosslinking HA into biomaterials affects of size-dependent responses of cells involved in SCI, 2) characterize how the degradation products of biomaterials fabricated from varying sizes of HA affect the regenerative potential of these cells, and 3) fabricate injectable, macroporous biomaterials with defined HA molecular weights and assess potential therapeutic effects after SCI in a mouse model. This proposal was able to support research investigating these goals, producing three publications with an additional one in preparation.

The first major outcome of this proposal was a study investigating the effects of HA hydrogels made with large HA on the growth and differentiation of neural stem cells (NSCs). This study demonstrated that large HA-based hydrogels are able to support the culture of NSCs for at least 70 days and have the ability to promote differentiation of NSCs into neurons and oligodendrocytes, while discouraging differentiation into inflammatory astrocytes (Seidlits et al., J. Biomed. Mater. Res. Part A., 2019). The second major outcome of this proposal was a study into the effectiveness of injectable, large HA-based macroporous, microparticle scaffolds for host tissue integration. Results from this study showed increased host cell infiltration and host tissue integration in these microparticle scaffolds compared to conventional nanoporous scaffolds after injection into mammary fat of mice (Ehsanipour et al., Cell. Mol. Bioeng., 2019). The third major outcome of this proposal was a study investigating how the size of the microparticles in these large HA-based macroporous, microparticle scaffolds influences host tissue integration, axon infiltration, and transgene delivery after SCI. Results showed that scaffolds made with either microparticles of uniform sizes or microparticles with a mixture of sizes were able to promote increased host cell and axon infiltration, integration with host tissue, and greater capacity for delivery of therapeutic transgenes when compared to conventional nanoporous hydrogels. However, scaffolds made with uniformly sized microparticles best supported axon infiltration and transgene delivery after SCI, which was improved, along with functional recovery, after delivery of a therapeutic transgene, brain-derived neurotrophic factor (Ehsanipour et al., APL Bioengineering, 2021). The fourth major outcome of this proposal was a study focusing on understanding the size effects on HA on blood vessel ingrowth into these HA-based macroporous, microparticle scaffolds as well as the mechanism underlying this bioactivity. Results from this study revealed that large HA is protective and pro-angiogenic in human brain microvascular endothelial cells, this bioactivity is not affected by crosslinking HA into microparticles, and clustering of the main HA receptor, CD44, in a size-dependent manner plays a role in this size-dependent bioactivity (Karam et al., in preparation).

While the above paragraph summarizes the intellectual merit, this project also contributed tremendously to the training of many scientists at the PhD, masters, and undergraduate levels, several of whom are underrepresented minorities (URM) and/or women. Additionally, the students working on this project participated in several programs to promote the participation and success of URM students in research such as the Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC) program, the University of California Leadership Excellence through Advanced Degrees (UC LEADS), and the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU). Broader impacts were also achieved through implementation of related research projects for Bioengineering Senior Capstone Design students and development of new support programs for trainees in biomedical science through the BME UNITE organization.

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2022
Modified by: Stephanie Seidlits
